channel.title: 经济学人
channel.description: 这是一个追踪经济学人news的种子

item.title: 一项新研究表明，几乎所有地方的腰围都在增加 👇
item.description:
A new study shows that waistlines are widening almost everywhere https://t.co/9nPlKkcjZM 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 24, 2024

item.title: 也门胡塞武装继续袭击红海和亚丁湾的船只，索马里海盗在印度洋卷土重来 👇
item.description:
As Houthi forces in Yemen continue to target ships in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden, Somali pirates are staging a comeback in the Indian Ocean https://t.co/XgVr317pJf 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 24, 2024

item.title: 在本期播客结束时，@TamaraGilkes 可能会决定成为一名合法枪支持有者。收听 "周末情报"，找出原因🎧。
item.description:
By the end of this podcast @TamaraGilkes might decide to become a legal gun-owner. Listen to “The Weekend Intelligence to find” out why https://t.co/PqTVTYJhxF 🎧

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 24, 2024

item.title: 人工智能音乐制作并不新鲜。但一些公司认为，他们已经找到了保留和复制用户 "独特音乐指纹 "的方法。
item.description:
AI music-making is nothing new. But some firms reckon that they have found a way to retain and reproduce the “unique musical fingerprint” of their users https://t.co/v3Ajg0d0cm

Illustration: Mark Pernice pic.twitter.com/mOHXX4vAwM

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 24, 2024

item.title: 英国最近并不是一个明显的模仿对象。英国为欧洲其他国家提供的主要服务是展示脱离欧盟的代价。但在一体化方面，英国却值得效仿。
item.description:
Britain has not been an obvious country to copy recently. Its major service to the rest of Europe has been to show the costs of leaving the EU. But on integration it is the place to beat https://t.co/8QdsJqo3Mq 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 24, 2024

item.title: 将欧盟 27 个国家整合为一个具有规模和决定性的盟友的新方法是必要的，但却难以实现。乌克兰可能更愿意选择一个大而不完美的盟友，而不是许多都有各自不同不足的小盟友👇。
item.description:
A new approach to meld the 27 countries of the EU into one sizeable and decisive ally is necessary yet elusive. Ukraine might well prefer one big yet imperfect ally to lots of smaller ones that all fall short in their own different ways https://t.co/XHOsYrwn4c 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 24, 2024

item.title: 在 "鼓楼 "节目中，我们探讨了习近平关于中国一党制国家是民主国家的说法，并询问中国公众是否同意这一说法 🎧。
item.description:
On “Drum Tower” we examine Xi Jinping’s claim that China’s one-party state is a democracy and ask whether the Chinese public agrees https://t.co/06TbnEgzsS 🎧

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 24, 2024

item.title: 争夺人工智能蛋糕的不仅仅是技术公司。各国都想分得更大的一杯羹。但是，如果说美国是大型科技公司，那么欧洲看起来更像是处于早期阶段的初创公司。现在，欧盟有了一个促进其产业发展的计划👇。
item.description:
It is not just technology firms that are fighting over the AI pie. Countries want a bigger slice. But if America is big tech, Europe looks more like an early-stage startup.

Now the EU has a plan to boost its industry https://t.co/Zo8fOvbHV8 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 24, 2024

item.title: 史蒂文-莱维特（Steven Levitt）和斯蒂芬-杜布纳（Stephen Dubner）在书中用应用微观经济学揭示了 "万事万物不为人知的一面"。这种方法很有趣，但传承有限👇。
item.description:
Steven Levitt and Stephen Dubner’s book used applied microeconomics to reveal “the hidden side of everything”.

The approach was fun, but has a limited legacy https://t.co/wLTfGNviXn 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 24, 2024

item.title: 中国的独生子女政策仍然困扰着中国的领导人。当地人说，即使在政策执行不那么严格的地区，20 多岁的年轻人也开始晚婚，而且只想要一两个孩子 👇
item.description:
China’s one-child policy still haunts the country’s leaders. Even in regions where the policy was enforced less strictly, 20-somethings are marrying later and wanting just one or two children, say locals https://t.co/jZpyYtoSQg 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 24, 2024

item.title: 发达国家青年男女之间日益扩大的差距令人震惊。要弄清其中的原因并不容易。但请阅读为什么这一趋势令人担忧，以及可以做些什么👇。
item.description:
The growing gulf between young men and women in developed countries is striking. Unpicking what is going on is not simple. But read why this trend is concerning, and what can be done about it https://t.co/OO9acrkR4l 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 24, 2024

item.title: M25 是英国最繁忙的公路，也是英国人最厌恶的公路之一。它的建成标志着英国从此不再钟情于高速公路 👇。
item.description:
The M25 is Britain’s busiest road—and also one of its most loathed. Its construction helped to mark the moment when the country fell out of love with motorways https://t.co/dZ0ye94Tfm 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 24, 2024

item.title: 英国政府每年额外支出 10 亿英镑用于儿童保育补贴。家长们越来越热衷于国家支持。政客们不再对传统家庭角色大惊小怪，而是更多地关注劳动力供应👇。
item.description:
Britain’s government is spending an extra £1bn per year on child-care subsidies. Parents have grown keener on state support. Politicians fuss less about traditional family roles and more about labour supply https://t.co/j7KA8HSSS6 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 24, 2024

item.title: 在英国政府手中，宪法上显而易见的声明--议会拥有按照自己的意愿立法的主权--被用来做任何政治上方便的事情。很快，这一立场在保守党人看来可能就不那么明智了👇。
item.description:
In the British government’s hands a statement of the constitutionally obvious—that Parliament is sovereign to legislate as it wishes—has been used to do whatever is politically convenient.

Soon that stance may not seem so smart to the Tories https://t.co/7cexS5l2EF 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 24, 2024

item.title: 查尔斯-达尔文（Charles Darwin）曾一度生活在恐惧之中，生怕自己的观点公开后会蒙羞。"不可能的怪物 "让人感受到相信和传播这些观点是多么危险。
item.description:
Charles Darwin once lived in fear of the disgrace that might accrue if his ideas became public. “Impossible Monsters” conveys a sense of just how risky it was to believe in and promulgate them https://t.co/JmRtYCQi5r 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 24, 2024

item.title: 莫斯科克洛库斯市政厅遇袭事件是对弗拉基米尔-普京及其所依赖的安全部门声誉的一次打击。至少 137 人丧生的袭击方式不会很快被人遗忘： 盖蒂
item.description:
The attack on the Crocus City Hall in Moscow is a blow to the reputation of Vladimir Putin and the security services on which he depends. The manner of the assault, in which at least 137 people lost their lives, will not soon be forgotten: https://t.co/QgecRdJDNv

Photo: Getty pic.twitter.com/fyo49d2anZ

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 24, 2024

item.title: 乔-拜登和唐纳德-特朗普对美国在世界上应有地位的理解存在 "严重缺陷"，@AmbJohnBolton 警告说。"让美国的敌人感到高兴的是，无论他们中的哪一个获胜，未来都将是漫长而严峻的四年。
item.description:
Joe Biden and Donald Trump have a “badly flawed” understanding of America’s proper place in the world, warns @AmbJohnBolton. “To the delight of America’s enemies, whichever of them wins, a long, grim four years lie ahead” https://t.co/lHqntcYLnK 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 24, 2024

item.title: 巴勒斯坦人担心他们的新政府首脑将为总统服务，而不是为人民服务 👇
item.description:
Palestinians fear their new head of government will serve their president, not the people https://t.co/d3NC50qB34 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 24, 2024

item.title: 弗拉基米尔-普京喜欢胜利，最好是舞台上的胜利。他不太善于应对计划外的挫折，更喜欢从舞台上消失。他对莫斯科袭击事件迟迟不作回应，这与我们熟悉的模式如出一辙 👇。
item.description:
Vladimir Putin likes victories, preferably stage-managed ones. He copes less well with unscheduled setbacks, preferring to disappear from the stage. His delayed response to the Moscow attack followed a familiar pattern https://t.co/H4pL6G8wwb 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 24, 2024

item.title: 在过去 35 年中，哪位美国领导人创造的就业机会最多？我们通过五张图表对过去八位总统进行了分析： 👇
item.description:
Which American leader of the last 35 years has created the most jobs?

Our analysis of the past eight presidents, in five charts: https://t.co/hJ9Y9FenuJ 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 24, 2024

item.title: 特姆优会赢得美国购物者的青睐吗？在本周的 "Money Talks "播客中，我们将问亚马逊和 Etsy 等公司应该如何担心中国电子商务巨头🎧？
item.description:
Will Temu win over American shoppers? This week on our “Money Talks” podcast, we ask how worried companies such as Amazon and Etsy should be about the Chinese e-commerce giant https://t.co/T6Ue9c8mwv 🎧

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 24, 2024

item.title: 美国联邦储备局仍需走完对抗通胀的最后一程。即使旅程结束，一个棘手的利率问题仍将存在👇。
item.description:
America’s Federal Reserve has still to travel the last mile in its fight against inflation.

Even once the journey comes to an end, a difficult interest-rate question will remain https://t.co/cPvJYcpnEd 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 24, 2024

item.title: 阳光之州为唐纳德-特朗普的宣传提供了线索--因为自由派看不起我，所以请投我一票吧 👇
item.description:
The Sunshine State offers clues as to why Donald Trump’s pitch—vote for me because liberals look down on me—works https://t.co/xvcKAmJ6rc 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 24, 2024

item.title: 美国的购房者和卖房者在目前的方式下并没有为佣金支付合理的价格。而与一群中介达成的和解协议并不能保证他们将来会有这样的机会👇。
item.description:
Homebuyers and sellers in America do not pay a fair price for commissions under the current approach. And a settlement agreed with a group of agents offers no guarantee that they will have such a chance in the future https://t.co/X8SlMrxJDv 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 24, 2024

item.title: 每周都有新高。难怪市场上弥漫着一种不安的情绪。对某些人来说，这种紧张预示着崩盘。但对每个人来说，这都会引发一个问题：股票价格已经上涨了这么多，还有什么股票是有价值的吗？ 👇
item.description:
Every week, a new high. Little wonder a sense of unease is settling over markets. For some, such nervousness portends a crash. But for everyone, it prompts a question: with stock prices having risen so much, are there any left that offer value? https://t.co/OC1AOHNTOs 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 24, 2024

item.title: "计算机视觉系统可以打败人类专家"在我们的 "巴贝奇 "特别迷你系列中，@加州理工学院的皮埃特罗-佩罗纳解释了人工智能是如何起飞的🎧。
item.description:
“Computer vision systems can beat human experts at their own game.”

Pietro Perona of @Caltech explains how AI took off, on our special “Babbage” mini-series https://t.co/P7E3zFXkIM 🎧

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 24, 2024

item.title: "在所有摇摆州中，亚利桑那州拥有最多的拉美裔选民"。@daniella_raz在我们的 "制衡 "播客中解释了为什么亚利桑那州是研究美国拉美裔投票的好地方🎧。
item.description:
“Of all the swing states it has the largest share of Hispanic voters.” @daniella_raz explains why Arizona is a good place to study America’s Latino vote, on our “Checks and Balance” podcast https://t.co/fiNkDjZPJF 🎧

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 24, 2024

item.title: 尼日利亚的高成本石油产业正在衰退。这将给出口和公共财政留下巨大缺口 👇
item.description:
Nigeria’s high-cost oil industry is in decline. That will leave a gaping hole in exports and public finances https://t.co/OX1tbKoCzx 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 24, 2024

item.title: 从纸面上看，欧洲人应该能够为乌克兰提供足够的支持。问题是，一个好盟友所需的特质分布不均：
item.description:
On paper, Europeans should be in a position to deliver more than enough support to Ukraine. The problem is that the attributes needed in a good ally are unevenly spread: https://t.co/XHjt6ga8Rh pic.twitter.com/sYYiCWaG7w

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 24, 2024

item.title: 我们还记得这位荷兰裔美国灵长类动物学家，他决心证明人类的每一种情感，其他灵长类动物也能感受到👇。
item.description:
When Frans de Waal looked into the eyes of a chimpanzee, an intelligent and self­-assured personality looked back.

We remember the Dutch-American primatologist who was determined to prove that every emotion humans felt, other primates felt too https://t.co/HRJXqCvhN5 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 24, 2024
